TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract _XDocument4 implements class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath._XDocument3

Docs.summary: This type is a wrapper for a COM interface implemented by a coclass that is required by managed code for COM interoperability. To access the members specified by this interface, use the type that wraps the coclass that implements this interface. For information about that type, including usage, remarks, and examples, see.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void CloseDocument() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Closes the form.

remarks.para: Calling the CloseDocument method is equivalent to calling the method of the collection.

example.para: In the following example, the CloseDocument method of the object is used to close the current form.
example.code: _XDocument3 thisDoc = (_XDocument3)thisXDocument; thisDoc.CloseDocument();
Dim thisDoc As _XDocument4 = DirectCast(_ thisXDocument, _XDocument4) thisDoc.CloseDocument()

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMDocument CreateDOM() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Creates a new instance of the XML Document Object Model (DOM) in memory.
Docs.returns: An IXMLDOMDocument that can be accessed from a new instance of the XML Document Object Model (DOM).

remarks.para: Using the CreateDOM method to create an instance of the XML DOM is equivalent to using the following method of creating a Microsoft XML Core Services (MSXML) 5.0 DOMDocument object:
Note: When automating InfoPath, the setProperty method of the IXMLDOMDocument2 object may fail for secondary data sources. To use the setProperty method, follow this example:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property DataAdapters As DataAdaptersCollection

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the collection that is associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: To use the object returned by a DataAdaptersCollection object, you must declare and cast to the corresponding type for the kind of data connection that is defined in the form template using the Data Connections command on the Data tab. For example, to work with a data connection to a SharePoint list, you must declare and cast the object returned from the DataAdaptersCollection object to the type as shown in the code sample.

example.para: In the following example, the DataAdapters property of the object is used to set a reference to a data connection to a SharePoint list called "Contacts".
example.code: SharepointListAdapterObject myContacts = (SharepointListAdapterObject)thisXDocument.DataAdapters["Contacts"];
Dim myContacts As SharepointListAdapterObject = _ DirectCast(_ thisXDocument.DataAdapters["Contacts"], _ SharepointListAdapterObject)

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property DataObjects As DataObjectsCollection

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the collection that is associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The DataObjects collection provides programmatic access to a form's secondary data sources. Each secondary data source is contained in a object within the DataObjects collection.

example.para: In the following example, the DataObjects property of the object is used to set a reference to the "CityList" secondary data source:
example.code: DataSourceObject myDataObject = (DataSourceObject)thisXDocument.DataObjects["CityList"];
Dim myDataObject As DataSourceObject = _ DirectCast(thisXDocument.DataObjects["CityList"], DataSourceObject)
example.para: In the following example, implemented as an event handler for a button on a form, the DataObjects property of the object is used to set a reference to the collection. The code then loops through the collection and displays the positional index and name of each object that it contains:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property DOM As IXMLDOMDocument

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a form's underlying XML document in the form of an XML Document Object Model (DOM).

remarks.para: A key property of the XDocument object, the DOM property allows you to programmatically access and manipulate the source XML of a form. After you have set a reference to the XML DOM, which contains the source XML data of a form, you can use any of the properties and methods that are supported by the XML DOM.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Errors As ErrorsCollection

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the that is associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The Errors collection is associated with a form's underlying XML document so that when an error occurs, it occurs within the XML document. After you set a reference to the Errors collection, you can access all of its properties and methods for managing the errors within an InfoPath form.

example.para: In the following example, the Errors property of the object is used to return the count of the number or errors and then display that value in a message box:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Extension As Object
public: property System::Object ^ Extension { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the global scripting object, which exposes the functions and global variables contained in a Microsoft InfoPath form's primary form code file.

remarks.para: The Extension object facilitates using the functions and global variables implemented in an InfoPath form's scripting file. Usually, it is used from a custom task pane, from a custom dialog box, or in the XSL Transformation (XSLT) of a view where direct access to the functions and variables may be needed.

To use the Extension object within a custom task pane, you must first set a reference to the XDocument object by using the Dynamic HTML (DHTML) external property of the DHTML window object, as shown in this example:

example.para: In the following example, the Extension property is used through the interface to invoke the custom method called . This is necessary when using the Extension property in managed code:
In the following example, a method called of the InfoPath project class can be accessed from the custom task pane using the Extension property:
To access from the custom task pane, use the DHTML external property of the DHTML window object:
example.code: objXDocument = window.external.XDocument; myString = objXDocument.Extension.myCustomMethod();

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance string GetDataVariable([in]int32 lVariableNumber) runtime managed
Public Function GetDataVariable (lVariableNumber As Integer) As String

Docs.summary: Gets the value of the specified variable, which is a predefined variable stored as a processing instruction attribute in the form's underlying XML document.
Docs.returns: The value of the specified variable, which is a predefined variable stored as a processing instruction attribute in the form's underlying XML document.

remarks.para: If the variable is not defined or is empty, the GetDataVariable method will return an empty string. To set a variable, use the method.

Note: InfoPath only supports using the variable, which is the variable used to specify the initial view displayed when a form is opened. The number of this variable is always 1, and its value must be the name of a view within the form.

example.para: In the following example, the GetDataVariable method of the object is used to return the value of the first variable:
example.code: string variable1; variable1= thisXDocument.GetDataVariable(1);

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMDocument GetDOM([in]string bstrName) runtime managed
Public Function GetDOM (bstrName As String) As IXMLDOMDocument

Docs.param: The name of a DataObject object.
Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the XML Document Object Model (DOM) of the specified object associated with the object.
Docs.returns: An IXMLDOMDocument of the XML Document Object Model (DOM) of the specified DataObject object associated with the XDocument object.

remarks.para: After you have a reference to the XML DOM that the GetDOM method returns, you can use any of the properties and methods that the XML DOM supports to manipulate the data that the DOM contains.

example.para: In the following example, the GetDOM method of the object is used to set a reference to the XML DOM that it returns, which in this case is the
object named "CityDropDownList":
example.code: IXMLDOMDocument city = thisXDocument.GetDOM("CityDropDownList");

MemberSignature.Value: public string GetNamedNodeProperty (object varMainDOMNode, string bstrPropertyName, string bstrDefaultValue);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance string GetNamedNodeProperty([in]object varMainDOMNode, [in]string bstrPropertyName, [in]string bstrDefaultValue) runtime managed
Public Function GetNamedNodeProperty (varMainDOMNode As Object, bstrPropertyName As String, bstrDefaultValue As String) As String
public: System::String ^ GetNamedNodeProperty(System::Object ^ varMainDOMNode, System::String ^ bstrPropertyName, System::String ^ bstrDefaultValue);
abstract member GetNamedNodeProperty : obj * string * string -> string

Docs.param: An XML node corresponding to a nonattribute node in the main data source, for which a named property is to be returned.
Specifies the name of the property whose value is to be returned.
Specifies the default value to be returned if the property has not been set.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of a named property for the specified XML node, which must be a nonattribute node in the main data source.
Docs.returns: The named property for the specified XML node, which must be a nonattribute node in the main data source.

remarks.para: Named properties allow users to associate strings with user-defined properties of XML element nodes in the main data source. The value of a named property can be set by using the method. Use the GetNamedNodeProperty method to read the value of a named property.

example.para: The following example demonstrates setting and getting the value of a named property (with the name "cost") of an XML node (called "item"):
In the following XSL example, the "cost" named property of the item node is displayed:
example.code: <xsl:value-of select="xdXDocument:GetNamedNodeProperty(item, 'cost', 'empty')"/>

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object GetWorkflowTasks() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTasks collection for the current form.
Docs.returns: A Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTasks collection that contains any Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTask objects for the current form.

remarks.para: Important: For the GetWorkFlowTasks method to work, you must establish a reference to the Microsoft Office 14.0 Object Library (from the COM tab of the Add Reference dialog box in Visual Studio. This will establish a reference to the Microsoft.Office.Core namespace, which contains the WorkflowTasks class.

example.para: In the following example, the GetWorkflowTasks method is used to display the count of workflow tasks associated with the current form.
This example requires a using or Imports directive for the Microsoft.Office.Core namespace in the declarations section of the form code module.
example.code:
Dim thisDoc As _XDocument4 = DirectCast(_ thisXDocument, _XDocument4) Dim myWorkflowTasks As WorkflowTasks = _ DirectCast(thisDoc.GetWorkflowTasks(), WorkflowTasks)
Dim workflowTasksCount As Integer = myWorkflowTasks.Count
thisXDocument.UI.Alert("Get " & workflowTasksCount.ToString() & " _ workflow tasks.")

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object GetWorkflowTemplates() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTemplates collection for the current form.
Docs.returns: A Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTemplates collection that contains any Microsoft.Office.Core.WorkflowTemplate objects for the current form.

remarks.para: Important: For the GetWorkFlowTemplates method to work, you must establish a reference to the Microsoft Office 14.0 Object Library (from the COM tab of the Add Reference dialog box in Visual Studio). This will establish a reference to the Microsoft.Office.Core namespace, which contains the WorkflowTemplates class.

example.para: In the following example, the GetWorkflowTemplates method is used to display the count of workflow templates associated with the current form.
This example requires a using or Imports directive for the Microsoft.Office.Core namespace in the declarations section of the form code module.
example.code:
Dim thisDoc As _XDocument4 = DirectCast(_ thisXDocument, _XDocument4) Dim myWorkflowTemplates As WorkflowTemplates = _ DirectCast(thisDoc.GetWorkflowTemplates(), WorkflowTemplates)
Dim workflowTemplatesCount As Integer = myWorkflowTemplates.Count
thisXDocument.UI.Alert("Get " & workflowTemplatesCount.ToString() & " _ workflow templates.")

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Host As Object
public: property System::Object ^ Host { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a System.Object that code running in a hosted instance of InfoPath can use to access the object model of the host application.
Docs.value: A that represents the method defined in the host application for accessing that application's object model..

remarks.para: This property is only used for scenarios where InfoPath is hosted as a control in another application and code running in InfoPath needs to access the object model of the host application. By default, the value of this property is set to a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

For a brief overview of hosting InfoPath in another application, see "The InfoPath Editor Hosted as a Control" in What's New for InfoPath Developers. For detailed information about hosting InfoPath as a control in another application, see the article titled "Hosting the InfoPath Form Editing Environment in a Custom Web Form" on the InfoPath Developer Portal

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property HostName As String
public: property System::String ^ HostName { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the name of the application hosting InfoPath as a control.
Docs.value: The name of the host application.

remarks.para: This property is intended for use in scenarios where InfoPath is hosted as a control in another application and code running in InfoPath needs to access the name of the host application. Typically the host application name returned will be used in the title bar text of dialog boxes instead of "Microsoft Office InfoPath".

For detailed information about hosting InfoPath as a control in another application, see the article titled "Hosting the InfoPath Form Editing Environment in a Custom Web Form" on the InfoPath Developer Portal

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ImportDOM([in]class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMDocument pxDoc) runtime managed

Docs.param: The XML data that is to be imported (merged) into the currently open form.
Docs.summary: Imports the specified XML data into the current form.

remarks.para: Using the object model to import a form programmatically is equivalent to performing a merge operation in the user interface.

example.para: In the following example, the ImportDOM method of the object is used to import a form from the event:

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ImportFile([in]string bstrFileURI) runtime managed

Docs.param: The Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) of the form that is to be imported (merged) into the currently open form.
Docs.summary: Imports the specified form into the current form.

remarks.para: Using the object model to programmatically import a form is equivalent to performing a merge operation in the user interface.

example.para: In the following example, the ImportFile method of the object is used to import a form:
example.code: thisXDocument.ImportFile(@"C:\SomeOtherForm.xml");

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property InputParameters As InputParameterCollection

Docs.summary: Gets an object containing any input parameters specified using the /InputParameters command-line option, or specified using query parameters in a URL.

remarks.para: Input parameters consist of one or more name/value pairs separated by the ampersand (&) character that are specified when a form template is opened from the command line or a batch file using the /InputParameters command-line option. Input parameters can also be specified using query parameters when a form template is opened from a URL.

example.para: In the following example, an InfoPath form template is opened from the command line using the following syntax:
infopath.exe "C:\User Forms\DeptReport.xsn" /InputParameters "Dept=Accounting"
example.code: string vDept = (_XDocument4)thisXDocument.InputParameters["Dept"];
Dim vDept As String = DirectCast(thisXDocument, _XDocument4).InputParameters("Dept")

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsDirty As Boolean
public: property bool IsDirty { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the data in a Microsoft InfoPath form has been modified since it was last saved.

remarks.para: If the IsDirty property is true, data in the form's underlying XML document has been changed since it was last saved. If false, no changes have occurred.
Note: Changes that occur during an event will not result in the IsDirty property being set to true.

example.para: In the following example, the IsDirty property of the object is used to determine whether data in the form has been changed:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsDOMReadOnly As Boolean
public: property bool IsDOMReadOnly { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the data in the underlying XML document of a Microsoft InfoPath form has been placed in a read-only state.

remarks.para: If the IsDOMReadOnly property is true, data in the form's underlying XML document is in a read-only state and cannot be changed. If false, the data in the form's underlying XML document can be changed.
To determine whether the form has been placed in a read-only state, use the property
The data in a form's XML document will be placed in a read-only state in the following scenarios:

item.description: The form is in Reduced Functionality Mode (RFM) mode
During an undo or redo operation

example.para: In the following example, the IsDOMReadOnly property of the object is used to determine whether data in the form's underlying XML document has been placed in a read-only state. If it has, a return statement is used to exit the event handler.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsHosted As Boolean
public: property bool IsHosted { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether InfoPath is hosted as a control in another application.
Docs.value: true if InfoPath is hosted as a control in another application; otherwise false.

remarks.para: This property is intended for use in scenarios where InfoPath is hosted as a control in another application.
For detailed information about hosting InfoPath in another application, see the article titled "Hosting the InfoPath Editor in a Custom WinForm Application" on the InfoPath Developer Portal

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsNew As Boolean
public: property bool IsNew { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a newly created Microsoft InfoPath form has been saved.

remarks.para: If the IsNew property is true, data in the form's underlying XML document has not been saved since the form was initially created. If false, the data in the new form's underlying XML document has been saved.

example.para: In the following example, the IsNew property of the object is used to determine whether the data in a new form has been saved:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsReadOnly As Boolean
public: property bool IsReadOnly { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a Microsoft InfoPath form is in read-only mode.

remarks.para: If the IsReadOnly property is true, the form has been placed in a read-only state. Changes can still be made to the form, but it cannot be saved using a save operation, it must be saved using a save-as operation.
To determine whether the form's underlying XML document has been placed in a read-only state, use the property.

example.para: In the following example, the IsReadOnly property of the object is used to determine whether the form is in a read-only state:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsRecovered As Boolean
public: property bool IsRecovered { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a Microsoft InfoPath form was last saved by an AutoRecover save operation.

example.para: The following example shows how to use the IsRecovered property to indicate, when the form is opened, whether the form was last saved by an AutoRecover save operation:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsSigned As Boolean
public: property bool IsSigned { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a Microsoft InfoPath form has been digitally signed using digital signatures.

remarks.para: If the IsSigned property is true, the form has been digitally signed. If false, the form has not been digitally signed.
InfoPath uses XML Signatures to digitally sign forms.
Note: If a form has been digitally signed, its underlying XML document is placed in a read-only state.

example.para: In the following example, the IsSigned property of the object is used to determine whether a form has been digitally signed:

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Language { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Language : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a Microsoft InfoPath form's default language code.

remarks.para: The language settings for an InfoPath form can also be accessed using the property.

example.para: In the following example, the Language property of the object is used to display a form's current language setting in a message box:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Alert("The current language is: " + thisXDocument.Language);

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property NetworkState As XDNetworkState

Docs.summary: Gets a object that provides information about the connection state of the client computer or whether a connection can be made to the specified network destination.
Docs.value: An object that provides information about the connection state of the client computer or whether a connection can be made to the specified network destination.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void NotifyHost([in]string bstrNotification) runtime managed

Docs.param: A custom value that will be used by the code in the hosting application or ASPX page.
Docs.summary: Provides a custom value to the hosting application or ASPX page.

remarks.para: The NotifyHost method is intended for use in scenarios where an InfoPath form template is hosted in an Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.XmlFormView control on an ASPX page running from Microsoft SharePoint Server 2010 with InfoPath Forms Services. The value you provide for the parameter is a string that can be used by the code-behind of the host ASPX page to perform a custom action.
For information about hosting an InfoPath form template in an ASPX page, see the article titled "Hosting the InfoPath Form Editing Environment in a Custom Web Form" on the InfoPath Developer Portal

The NotifyHost method can also be used when the InfoPath application is itself hosted as a control in another application, although in that scenario you would typically use the property to retrieve a custom object for working with the host application's object model instead.

For information about hosting InfoPath as a control in another application, see the article titled "Hosting the InfoPath 2007 Form Editing Environment in a Custom Web Form" on the InfoPath Developer Portal

example.para: The following example shows what the event handler in the code-behind of an ASPX page would need look like in order to receive the string value provided by the NotifyHost method. In this example, the NotifyHost method would be providing "ActionA" as the parameter, and the event handler would perform a conditional action when the value is received.
example.code: Private Sub XmlFormView1_NotifyHost(sender As Object, _ e As NotifyHostEventArgs) If (e.Notification = "ActionA") Then ' Code to perform if 'ActionA' is received. Else ' Code to perform an alternative action. End If End Sub

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Permission As PermissionObject

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a object associated with the form.
Docs.value: A object that represents the Information Rights Management (IRM) permission settings for the form.

remarks.para: After a reference to the PermissionObject object is returned, it can be used to restrict permissions to the active form and to return or set specific permissions settings, such as whether data in the form can be edited, copied, or printed.

example.para: In the following example, the Permission property to return a PermissionObject object for the current form, which then uses the property to display whether permission settings are enabled for the current form.
example.code: Dim thisDoc As _XDocument4 = _ DirectCast(thisXDocument, _XDocument4) thisXDocument.UI.Alert( thisDoc.Permission.Enabled.ToString())

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void PrintOut() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Prints the form content as it is rendered in the window corresponding to the form's active view.

remarks.para: The PrintOut method uses the current printer settings. Returns a permission denied error if called from a form that is not fully trusted.

It is recommended that you don't call the PrintOut method from the or events. You may encounter one or more of the following behaviors when calling the PrintOut method from an OnLoad or OnSwitchView event procedure:

item.description: A blank document may be printed.
The incorrect view may be printed.

example.para: In the following example, the PrintOut method of the object is used to print the current view:
example.code: thisXDocument.PrintOut();

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Query() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Retrieves data from a form's associated data adapter object and stores the data in the form's underlying XML Document Object Model (DOM).

remarks.para: The Query method will return an error if the form does not have an associated data adapter object.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property QueryAdapter As Object
public: property System::Object ^ QueryAdapter { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the data adapter object that is associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: Data adapter objects provide different properties and methods that retrieve and submit data to external data sources; the data adapter that is associated with a form is dependent on the type of data source that was used when the form was initially created.
The QueryAdapter property allows you to access an InfoPath form's primary data source. To access the data adapter objects used for a form's secondary data sources, use the property.

example.para: In the following example, the QueryAdapter property of the object is used to set a reference to the object; then the property of the ADOAdapter object is used to display the SQL command text in a message box:

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Role { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Role : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the user's current role.

example.para: In the following example, the Role property is used to determine the current user's role.
example.code: string currentRole = thisXDocument.Role;

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Save() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Saves the form to the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) that it is currently associated with.

remarks.para: The Save method will return an error if called from a form that is not fully trusted.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SaveAs([in]string bstrFileUrl) runtime managed

Docs.param: The URL address that the form should be saved to.
Docs.summary: Saves the form to the specified Uniform Resource Locator (URL).

remarks.para: The SaveAs method will return an error if called from a form that is not fully trusted.
Note: The URL that the form is saved to must be in the same domain as the form that calls the SaveAs method.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ServerInfo As ServerInfoObject

Docs.summary: Gets a object that provides information about the SharePoint server where the form is located.
Docs.value: An object that provides information about the SharePoint server where the form is located.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetDataVariable (int lVariableNumber, string bstrVariableValue);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetDataVariable([in]int32 lVariableNumber, [in]string bstrVariableValue) runtime managed
Public Sub SetDataVariable (lVariableNumber As Integer, bstrVariableValue As String)
public: void SetDataVariable(int lVariableNumber, System::String ^ bstrVariableValue);
abstract member SetDataVariable : int * string -> unit

Docs.summary: Sets the value of a predefined variable stored as a processing instruction attribute in the form's underlying XML document.

remarks.para: If the variable being set is not a valid processing instruction attribute, the SetDataVariable method will return an error.
To get the value of a variable, use the method.

Note: Microsoft InfoPath only supports using the variable, which is the variable used to specify the initial view displayed when a form is opened. The number of this variable is always 1, and its value must be the name of a view within the form.

example.para: In the following example, the SetDataVariable method of the object is used to set the value of the first variable:
example.code: thisXDocument.SetDataVariable(1, "View 2");

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetDirty([in]bool vfIsDirty) runtime managed

Docs.param: Specifies whether the form is to be marked as unmodified or not.
Docs.summary: Sets the property for the object, which indicates whether the data in a Microsoft InfoPath form has been modified since it was last saved.

remarks.para: The SetDirty method can be used from the event to force a document to be marked as unchanged. InfoPath will therefore not request the user to save the form when it is closed.
The SetDirty method can also be used from the event to programmatically mark the form as changed or unchanged since it was last saved.

example.para: In the following example, the IsDirty property of the current form is set to false so that the user will not be prompted to save the form when it is closed.
example.code: thisXDocument.SetDirty(false);

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetNamedNodeProperty (Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMNode pxmlMainDOMNode, string bstrPropertyName, string bstrValue);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetNamedNodeProperty([in]class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMNode pxmlMainDOMNode, [in]string bstrPropertyName, [in]string bstrValue) runtime managed
Public Sub SetNamedNodeProperty (pxmlMainDOMNode As IXMLDOMNode, bstrPropertyName As String, bstrValue As String)
public: void SetNamedNodeProperty(Microsoft::Office::Interop::InfoPath::Xml::IXMLDOMNode ^ pxmlMainDOMNode, System::String ^ bstrPropertyName, System::String ^ bstrValue);
abstract member SetNamedNodeProperty : Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.Xml.IXMLDOMNode * string * string -> unit

Docs.param: An XML node corresponding to a nonattribute node in the main data source, for which a named property is to be set.
Specifies the name of the property being set.
Specifies the value to which the property will be set.
Docs.summary: Sets the value of a named property for the supplied XML node, which must be a nonattribute node in the main data source.

remarks.para: Named properties allow users to associate strings with user-defined properties of XML element nodes in the main data source. The value of a named property can be set by using the SetNamedNodeProperty method. Use the method to read the value of a named property.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property SignedDataBlocks As SignedDataBlocksCollection

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the collection that is associated with an object.

example.para: In the following example, the SignedDataBlocks property of the XDocument object is used to get a reference to the SignedDataBlocksCollection collection. An individual object is then accessed using array indexing:
example.code: SignedDataBlocksCollection sblocks = thisXDocument.SignedDataBlocks; SignedDataBlockObject sdblock = sblocks[0];

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Solution As SolutionObject

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the object that is associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The Solution property provides access to information about a form's associated form definition (.xsf) file, including access to an XML Document Object Model (DOM) that contains all of the source XML of the .xsf file.

example.para: In the following example, the Solution property of the object is used to load a variable with the XML contents of the .xsf file:
example.code: string xsf; xsf = thisXDocument.Solution.DOM.xml;

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Submit() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Executes the predefined submit operation in a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: Using the Submit method is similar to, but not exactly like, using the submit operation from the InfoPath user interface. Calling the Submit method simply performs the submit operation, but the submit operation must first be enabled for a form in design mode.
Note: You can write a custom submit operation using the event, and then you can programmatically call the event using the Submit method.

example.para: In the following example, the Submit method of the object is used to submit the form using the predefined submit operation:
example.code: thisXDocument.Submit();

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property UI As UIObject

Docs.summary: Returns a reference to object.

remarks.para: The UI (user interface) object provides a number of methods that can be used to display custom and built-in dialog boxes.

example.para: In the following example, the UI property of the object is used to display a simple message box using the method:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Alert("Here is the message text.");

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property URI As String
public: property System::String ^ URI { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) of a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The URI property can be used as the name of a form when accessed through the collection.

example.para: In the following example, the URI property of the object is used to display a form's URI in a message box:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Alert("URI:" + thisXDocument.URI);

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property User As UserObject

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a object.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Util As UtilObject

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to a object.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property View As ViewObject

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The ViewObject object accessed by the View property represents the view that is currently active in an InfoPath form. After you have set a reference to the ViewObject object, you can access any of its properties and methods to programmatically interact with the view.

example.para: In the following example, the View property of the XDocument object is used to set a reference to the View object; then, using the property of the ViewObject object, it displays the name of the view in a message box:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Alert("View name: " + thisXDocument.View.Name);

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ViewInfos As ViewInfosCollection

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the collection associated with a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The ViewInfos collection contains a collection of object containing information about each of the views implemented in an InfoPath form.

example.para: In the following example, the property of the object is used to set a reference to the ViewInfosCollection collection; then, using the property of the ViewInfosCollection collection, it loops through the collection to determine the default view using the property of the ViewInfoObject object. When the default view is found, the code displays the name of the view in a message box.
example.code: ViewInfos viewInfos; viewInfos = thisXDocument.ViewInfos; for (int i=0; i < viewInfos.Count; i++) { if (viewInfos[i].IsDefault) { thisXDocument.UI.Alert("The default view is: " + viewInfos[i].Name); } }
